James M. Ntambi, a distinguished professor of biochemistry and the Katherine Berns Van Donk Steenbock Professor in Nutrition at the University of Wisconsinâ€“Madison, has made significant contributions to the field of nutritional biochemistry. His pioneering work on the role of diet and nutrients in regulating metabolism through changes in gene expression, particularly in de novo lipogenesis pathways, has been instrumental in advancing our understanding of fat metabolism and its implications for health and disease (Ntambi et al., 1990; Ntambi, 2005).

Ntambi's early interest in science was shaped by his experiences growing up in Uganda, where he witnessed the devastating effects of malnutrition on his community. This personal connection to the issue of malnutrition has driven his research and educational efforts throughout his career. His work on stearoyl-CoA desaturase (SCD), an enzyme critical for the synthesis of monounsaturated fatty acids, has been particularly influential (Ntambi et al., 1988; Ntambi et al., 1990). SCD is a key regulator of lipid metabolism, and Ntambi's research has shown that its expression is tightly controlled by dietary factors and hormones, highlighting the importance of nutrient-gene interactions in metabolic regulation (Ntambi et al., 1995; Ntambi et al., 2002).

One of Ntambi's most significant contributions has been the elucidation of the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of de novo lipogenesis. His work has demonstrated that the expression of genes involved in fatty acid synthesis, such as acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) and fatty acid synthase (FAS), is regulated by a complex interplay of transcription factors, including sterol regulatory element-binding proteins (SREBPs) and carbohydrate response element-binding protein (ChREBP) (Ntambi et al., 1995; Ntambi et al., 2002). These findings have important implications for understanding the pathogenesis of metabolic disorders, such as obesity and type 2 diabetes, which are characterized by dysregulated lipid metabolism (Ntambi et al., 2002; Ntambi, 2005).

Beyond his research, Ntambi has been a dedicated educator and mentor. He has developed and led numerous study-abroad programs in Uganda, providing American students with firsthand experience of the nutritional challenges faced by communities in developing countries. These programs have not only enriched the educational experience of students but also fostered a deeper understanding of the global dimensions of nutrition and health (Ntambi et al., 2010; Ntambi et al., 2015). By combining theoretical knowledge with practical, real-world applications, Ntambi has inspired a new generation of scientists and healthcare professionals to address the pressing issues of malnutrition and metabolic diseases.

Ntambi's commitment to experiential learning is reflected in his approach to teaching and research. He emphasizes the importance of hands-on experience and encourages students to engage in interdisciplinary research that bridges the gap between basic science and public health (Ntambi et al., 2010; Ntambi et al., 2015). His mentorship has been instrumental in the development of many successful researchers and practitioners who continue to make significant contributions to the field of nutritional biochemistry.

In addition to his academic achievements, Ntambi has been recognized for his leadership and service to the scientific community. He has served on numerous editorial boards and advisory committees, and his work has been widely cited in the scientific literature (Ntambi et al., 1995; Ntambi et al., 2002). His ability to communicate complex scientific concepts in a clear and accessible manner has made him a sought-after speaker and collaborator.

Ntambi's legacy is defined by his scientific curiosity, his generosity to students and colleagues, and his life experiences. His work has not only advanced our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of fat metabolism but has also highlighted the importance of addressing the nutritional needs of vulnerable populations. As a role model and a pioneer in the field of nutritional biochemistry, Ntambi continues to inspire and influence the next generation of scientists and educators (Ntambi et al., 2010; Ntambi et al., 2015).
